Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Grey Nearing of the University of Arizona to conduct a research project, entitled "An approach to evaluate the value of data assimilation," during the summer of 2012 at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Dawen Yang.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the development of a method to estimate the utility of a general probabilistic data assimilation filter or smoother and to disassociate effects data assimilation inefficiency due to filter assumptions from inefficiency due to observations and the model, e.g. non-injectivity of the observation function and nonlinear state correlations.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Outcomes Report

NSF Grant #1208294

 

This project titled On the Value of Bayesian Approaches for Improving Estimates of Agricultural Yield using Remotely Sensed Observations represents a major step forward in understanding common methods for merging model predictions and satellite-based remote sensing observations. This process of merging models and observations is called data assimilation (Wikle and Berliner 2007) and is used widely in many areas of science. The method we propose can be used to analyze the efficiency of data assimilation and is useful and universal. Specifically, we demonstrated that data assimilation with radar wavelength satellite observations related to soil moisture results in heavy information losses while data assimilation with observations related to crop greenness from optical and infra-red wavelength satellites results in low information losses. These findings might be used in the future to guide data collection and assimilation strategies for monitoring global food production.

Data assimilation is used in many scientific and engineering disciplines including adaptive navigation systems (Zhang 2010), computer vision (Welch 2009) and machine learning (e.g., Deisenroth et al. 2009), numerical weather prediction (Navon 2009), and economics , (Pasricha 2006). The methods we propose are relevant to any activity which uses this type of approach to combine dynamic time-evolving information sources.

The ability to use computer models to make predictions of natural and anthropologic systems is of vital importance. One very common approach to improving the predictive power of forecasting models is to condition these models on available data, and one of the most common ways to do this is by data assimilation. This NSF funded has the potential to be valuable to the development of computer-based predictive systems in many disciplines. Current social and economic value of such computer-aided systems is very large and this work contributes represents a significant and novel contribution to this larger effort.
